heading.title: Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (NSW)
UNIFORM CIVIL PROCEDURE RULES 2005
PART 51 COURT OF APPEAL [rr 51.1–51.61]
DIVISION 8 MISCELLANEOUS [rr 51.46–51.61]
Subdivision 2 Powers of Court [rr 51.50–51.55] 2 of 2

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.53] r 51.53 Circumstances in which Court may order new trial (cf SCR Part 51, rule 23)

leg:heading.title: Circumstances in which Court may order new trial (cf SCR Part 51, rule 23)

p.text: The Court may order a new trial on any question without interfering with the decision on any other question.

If it appears to the Court that some ground for a new trial affects part only of the matter in controversy, or one or some only of the parties, the Court may order a new trial as to that part only, or as to that party or those parties only.
If the Court makes an order under subrule (2) or (3), it may give such judgment or make such order as the nature of the case requires for the disposal of the remainder of the appeal.
If the Court orders a new trial, the Court may:
impose conditions on any party for the purposes of the new trial, and
direct admissions to be made by any party for the purpose of the new trial, and
order that the testimony of any witness examined at the former trial may be read from the transcript, instead of the witness being again examined.

heading.title: Bias — other apprehensions of pre-judgment

p.text: When pre-judgment of an issue is relied upon as the basis of apprehended bias, "what must be firmly established is a reasonable fear that the decision-maker's mind is so prejudiced in favour of a conclusion already formed that he or she will not alter that conclusion irrespective of the evidence or arguments presented": Re JRL; Ex parte CJL (1986) 161 CLR 342 at 352, 360, 371; 10 ALN N184; 66 ALR 239; BC8601444 ; Laws v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (1990) 170 CLR 70 at 100; 93 ALR 435; 64 ALJR 412; BC9002913 ; Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Jia (2001) 205 CLR 507; 178 ALR 421; [2001] HCA 17; BC200101234 at [72]. That reasonable fear must be "firmly established" because it is to be expected that judicial officers may have formed views or "inclinations of mind" with respect to particular subjects in the course of their professional careers: R v Australian Stevedoring Industry Board; Ex parte Melbourne Stevedoring Co Pty Ltd (1953) 88 CLR 100 at 116; [1953] ALR 461; (1953) 27 ALJR 35; BC5300260 ; R v Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission; Ex parte Angliss Group (1969) 122 CLR 546 at 553–554; [1969] ALR 504; BC6900660 ; R v Watson; Ex parte Armstrong (1976) 136 CLR 248 at 261–262; 9 ALR 551; 1 Fam LR 11,297; BC7600059 .

In CUR24 v DPP [2012] NSWCA 65; BC201202033 the question raised was whether indiscreet comments by a judge at a social function, not directed to any particular case or litigant, but to a class of criminal behavior, gave rise to a reasonable apprehension of bias, in the sense of pre-judgment. The application was dismissed. Judicial officers may have formed views with respect to subjects that they are likely to have to address in the course of their professional careers. It does not follow that because such a view or opinion is held, the officer is to be regarded as so prejudiced that they will not put that view aside and be capable of impartially considering the evidence or argument presented in trial: CUR24 v DPP [2012] NSWCA 65; BC201202033 at [59]. A fair minded observer is to be taken to appreciate these matters. A judge is someone whose “training, tradition and oath or affirmation require [that they] discard the irrelevant, the immaterial and the prejudicial”: Johnson v Johnson (2000) 201 CLR 488; 174 ALR 655; [2000] HCA 48; BC200005268 at [12]. British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Laurie (2011) 242 CLR 283; 273 ALR 429; [2011] HCA 2; BC201100308 at [46]–[47], [80]–[81] and [132].

level.toc-caption: [51.53.75] Procedure for applications involving an allegation of bias

heading.title: Procedure for applications involving an allegation of bias

p.text: No formal procedure is required to support a bias disqualification application: Idoport Pty Ltd v National Australia Bank Ltd [2004] NSWSC 270; BC200402171 ; British American Tobacco Australia Ltd v Gordon [2007] NSWSC 109; BC200700912 at [52] (notice of motion for disqualification not necessary, proceeded informally); Kartinyeri v Commonwealth [1998] HCA 52; BC9804130 per Callinan J (no formal motion filed and was not necessary); Bainton v Rajski (1992) 29 NSWLR 539 at 544 (no motion for disqualification or hearing of evidence necessary); S&M Motors Pty Ltd v Caltex Oil (Aust) Pty Ltd (1988) 12 NSWLR 358; (1988) 91 FLR 175; (1988) 11 IPR 97 (motion filed); J Aron Corp v Newmont Yandal Operations Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 720; BC200605505 (motion filed). The very nature of the application may permit or require some flexibility of procedure in informing the judge of the basis for the application: Bainton v Rajski (1992) 29 NSWLR 539 at 544D, 548C .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.80] Appeals in relation to bias applications

heading.title: Appeals in relation to bias applications

p.text: A trial judge's refusal to disqualify themself for alleged bias is not an actual order or judgment and cannot be the subject of a direct appeal or otherwise challenged by a claim for a declaration or prerogative orders: Barton v Walker [1979] 2 NSWLR 740 . Lee v Cha [2008] NSWCA 13; BC200800876 (see discussion by Basten JA at [15] and following). See Dr M Perry, “Disqualification of Judges: Practice and Procedure”, discussion paper, Australian Institute of Judicial Administration, 2001. However a judge’s refusal to disqualify themselves for alleged bias can be raised on an appeal against the final judgment in the proceedings: Barton v Walker [1979] 2 NSWLR 740 ; Rogerson v R (1990) 45 A Crim R 253; BC9002790 ; Bainton v Rajski (1992) 29 NSWLR 539 ; Abram v National Australia Bank Ltd (NSWCA, Mason P, Priestley and Powell JJA, 1 May 1997, unreported, BC9701553) (appeal against contempt finding). It can also be raised, with leave, on any appeal from an interlocutory order in the proceedings: Michael Wilson & Partners Ltd v Nicholls (2011) 282 ALR 685; 86 ALJR 14; [2011] HCA 48; BC201109206 at [82] (explaining the limited scope of the ruling in Barton v Walker above); Rajski v Wood (1989) 18 NSWLR 512 at 518 ; Australian National Industries Ltd v Spedley Securities Ltd (in liq) (1992) 26 NSWLR 411 at 423; 9 ACSR 309 . Consequently, although a judge’s rejection of a recusal application cannot itself be the direct subject of an appeal, it can be the subject of an application for leave to appeal. This is especially the case where, as a result of refusing the recusal application, the trial judge has made other interlocutory orders in the proceedings. In such a case it will often be appropriate for a party to seek, and be granted, leave to appeal: see Barakat v Goristas [2012] NSWCA 8; BC201200419 and the subsequent proceedings in Barakat v Goritsas (No 2) [2012] NSWCA 36; BC201201169 at [64]. Conversely, a party’s unreasonable failure to seek leave to appeal may preclude the point being raised in any appeal from the final judgment in the proceedings: Michael Wilson & Partners Ltd v Nicholls (2011) 282 ALR 685; 86 ALJR 14; [2011] HCA 48; BC201109206 at [84].

level.toc-caption: [51.53.85] Adjournment or amendment — appeal against refusal of

heading.title: Adjournment or amendment — appeal against refusal of

p.text: The granting of applications for adjournments, or for leave to amend, is a matter within the discretion of the trial judge. However, an erroneous exercise of the discretion may provide a basis for an appeal and an order for a new trial: Sali v SPC Ltd (1993) 116 ALR 625; 67 ALJR 841; BC9303602 ; Squire v Rogers (1979) 27 ALR 330; 39 FLR 106 ; Conroy v Conroy (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 680 at 682 ; Maxwell v Keun [1928] 1 KB 645 at 650; [1927] All ER Rep 335 ; Sackville-West v A-G (1910) 128 LT 265 ; Re Yates Settlement Trusts [1954] 1 All ER 619; [1954] 1 WLR 564 ; Carryer v Kelly [1969] 2 NSWR 769; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 566 (adjournment); Union Bank of Australia v Raine (1894) 6 QLJ 58 (amendment); Proprietors — Strata Plan 2 0754 v Hawkesbury City Council (1991) 73 LGRA 199; BC9101591 (amendment). The refusal of an amendment or adjournment will constitute an appellable error if the trial judge took into account irrelevant considerations, failed to take proper account of relevant considerations or otherwise misconceived the nature and purpose of the discretion: Sophron v Nominal Defendant (1957) 96 CLR 469; 31 ALJR 395; BC5700210 . For example, an order for a new trial may be made where a party was taken by surprise in the conduct of trial and an application for an adjournment to permit them to meet the claim was wrongly rejected: Rowe v Australian United Steam Navigation Co Ltd (1909) 9 CLR 1; 15 ALR 339; BC0900040 ; Isaacs v Hobhouse [1919] 1 KB 398 ; Preston v Green (1944) 61 WN (NSW) 204 ; Jeffrey v Jeffrey (1931) 31 SR (NSW) 535 ; Lakeman v Jardine (1885) 2 WN (NSW) 17; Wilson v Wilson [1938] St R Qd 1 ; Thomas v R (1904) 2 CLR 127 .

heading.title: Misconduct of the jury

p.text: Evidence about the content of a jury's deliberations is not admissible: David Syme & Co Ltd v Swinburne (1909) 10 CLR 43; [1910] VLR 539 ; Shoukatallie v R [1962] AC 81; [1961] 3 All ER 996 ; cf Ellis v Deheer [1922] 2 KB 113 ; Prothonotary v Jackson [1976] 2 NSWLR 457 ; Attorney-General v New Statesman and Nation Publishing Co Ltd [1981] QB 1; [1980] 1 All ER 644; [1980] 2 WLR 246 . However, a new trial may be ordered if it can otherwise be shown that the jury has not properly performed its role. Thus a new trial may be ordered where a stranger has been permitted into the jury room: Goby v Wetherill [1915] 2 KB 654 ; where a juror has communicated with a witness: Perdriau v Moore (1888) 9 LR (NSW) L 143; where a juror has discussed the case with nonjurors: Trewartha v Confidence Extended Co NL [1906] VLR 285 ; where a juror has acquired evidence otherwise than in the course of the trial: Mapp v Stephens [1965] NSWR 1661 at 1669 ; where a juror is a member of a corporation which is a party: Atkins v Fulham Borough Council (1915) 31 TLR 564; or where the jury shows partiality against the party: Allum v Boultbee (1854) 23 LJ Ex 208. Furthermore, the confidentiality of the juror's formal deliberations does not extend to render inadmissible evidence of misconduct by jurors in relation to their jury deliberations: R v Young [1995] QB 324; [1995] 2 WLR 430 (group of jurors conducting a seance).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.95] Evidence — appeal against findings “against the evidence and against the weight of evidence”

heading.title: Evidence — appeal against findings “against the evidence and against the weight of evidence”

p.text: This is a commonly used ground of appeal where a jury verdict is impugned. It expresses the idea that the verdict was not reasonably open on the evidence: Metropolitan Railway Co v Wright (1886) 11 App Cas 152 at 155 ; Mechanical& General Inventions Co v Austin [1935] AC 346 at 373 ; Hocking v Bell (1947) 75 CLR 125; [1948] 1 ALR 85; BC4700350 . A distinction has been drawn between verdicts that are challenged as being “against the evidence” and those which are “against the weight of evidence”. In the former case, the evidence is said to be all one way: Mount Bischoff Tin Mining Co Registered v Mount Bischoff Extended Tin Mining Co (NL) (1913) 15 CLR 549 at 559 ; Hocking v Bell (1942) 42 SR (NSW) 130 at 132 ; Conlon v Divis [1967] 2 NSWR 6 at 10 ; Hook v Stephenson (1939) 9 ALJ 125. In the latter case, where a verdict is challenged as being “against the weight of evidence” a successful appellant must show that, even on the evidence least favourable to the appellant, a properly instructed jury could not have found for the respondent: Pujick v Savic, Cox and Cudgewa Dairy Co Ltd [1971] VR 632 ; Cox v English, Scottish and Australian Bank Ltd [1905] AC 168 at 170 ; Middleton v Melbourne Tramway & Omnibus Co Ltd (1913) 16 CLR 752; 19 ALR 523; [1914] VLR 19 . However, the reality of this distinction is doubtful. The better view is that this ground of appeal conveys a single idea — namely that the evidence is so preponderant that the jury's verdict is unreasonable: Waverley Municipal Council v Swain (2003) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-694; [2003] NSWCA 61; BC200301409 . Where this ground of appeal succeeds, the proper result is to order a new trial: Hocking v Bell (1947) 75 CLR 125; [1948] 1 ALR 85; BC4700350 ; Metropolitan Railway Co v Wright (1886) 11 App Cas 152 at 155 ; Mechanical & General Inventions Co v Austin [1935] AC 346 at 373 . A verdict for the defendant may only be ordered if, on the proper analysis, there is no evidence capable of sustaining the verdict: Waverley Municipal Council v Swain (2003) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-694; [2003] NSWCA 61; BC200301409 .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.100] Damages — appeal against excessive or inadequate assessment

heading.title: Damages — appeal against excessive or inadequate assessment

p.text: A new trial may, subject to the exercise of the court's powers under SCA s 107, be granted on the question of damages where the amount is so high (or low) as to be beyond what might properly have been awarded by a reasonable jury: Triggell v Pheeney (1951) 82 CLR 497 at 516; [1951] ALR 453 ; Carson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1993) 178 CLR 44; 67 ALJR 634 at 643; BC9303554 (damages for defamation); Progress and Properties Ltd v Craft (1976) 135 CLR 651; 12 ALR 59; BC7600100 ; Phillips v London & South Western Railway Co (1879) 5 QBD 78 ; Johnston v Great Western Railway [1904] 2 KB 250 ; Taff Vale Railway Co v Jenkins [1913] AC 1 ; Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 ; Flint v Lovell [1935] 1 KB 354 at 360 ; Mechanical & General Inventions Co v Austin [1935] AC 346 at 377 ; Davies v Powell Duffryn Associated Collieries Ltd [1942] AC 601 at 617 ; Australian Iron & Steel Ltd v Greenwood (1962) 107 CLR 308; [1963] ALR 710; BC6200200 and see Luntz, Assessment of Damages, 2nd ed, p 524. The court should not approach the case by comparing its own instinctive view with the amount of the verdict: Coyne v Citizen Finance Ltd (1991) 172 CLR 211; 99 ALR 252; BC9102642 (defamation proceedings). In assessing the propriety of a jury verdict an appellate court must take a view of the evidence that is most consistent with the size of the verdict returned: Progress and Properties Ltd v Craft (1976) 135 CLR 651 at 672; 12 ALR 59; BC7600100 . Where, even so, the size of the verdict is disproportionate, it may be possible to infer that some material consideration must have been overlooked or that the figure arrived at by the jury was reached as a compromise: Chapman v Ellesmere [1932] 2 KB 455; Pateman v Higgin (1957) 97 CLR 521; [1957] ALR 996; BC5700550 ; Black v Morton (1957) 75 WN (NSW) 196 ; Kortekaas v Maslen (1958) 58 SR (NSW) 224; 75 WN (NSW) 200; Houston v Longworth [1964-5] NSWR 17 at 19 ; Doyle v Indo-China Steam Navigation Co Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 263.

level.toc-caption: [51.53.105] Points not taken at trial — general restriction against raising on appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.53.105] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 36.16, 36.17.

heading.title: Points not taken at trial — general restriction against raising on appeal

p.text: The public policy favouring the finality of litigation, and the broad principles requiring the just and efficient conduct of proceedings, limit the circumstances in which parties may raise new matters, either at the conclusion of the hearing (as to which see UCPR rr 36.16 , 36.17 and their accompanying notes) or on an appeal. The general principle is that parties ought to be bound by the way they conduct the proceedings, and consequently disallowed from raising new matters on an appeal. Numerous cases confirm this principle and provide examples of its application: Coulton v Holcombe (1986) 162 CLR 1; 65 ALR 656; BC8601435 (validity of statutory notice); Water Board v Moustakas (1988) 180 CLR 491; 77 ALR 193; BC8802592 (new particulars of negligence); Suttor v Gundowda Pty Ltd (1950) 81 CLR 418 at 438; 24 ALJR 298 (discretionary defence to specific performance); O'Brien v Komesaroff (1982) 150 CLR 310; 41 ALR 255; BC8200080 (ownership of copyright); Davison v Vickery's Motors Ltd (in liq) (1925) 37 CLR 1 at 35; 31 ALR 465; BC2500013 (authority of agent); David Syme & Co Ltd v Swinburne (1909) 10 CLR 43; [1910] VLR 539 (failure to object to unsworn evidence).

The restriction on raising new matters on appeal applies even where the point is sought to be raised by the court itself rather than by one of the parties: Hoecheong Products Co Ltd v Cargill Hong Kong Ltd [1995] 1 WLR 404; [1995] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 584 . It has also been applied where the new matter sought to be raised is supported by an authority that was decided after the trial: Wilson v Liverpool City Council [1971] 1 All ER 628; [1971] 1 WLR 302 (where a point was not permitted to be raised even though it was supported by a subsequent House of Lords decision); see also Piening v Wanless (1968) 117 CLR 498 at 506; [1968] ALR 342; BC6800190 ; Eggins v Brooms Head Bowling & Recreational Club Ltd (1986) 5 NSWLR 521; (1986) Aust Torts Reports ¶80-044 (subsequent High Court decision); R v Unger [1977] 2 NSWLR 990 (regulation declared invalid); R v Knight [1998] 1 NZLR 583 . All of these authorities accord primary significance to the public interest in the finality of litigation as a sufficient basis for refusing parties permission to depart from the case presented at first instance: UTSA Pty Ltd (in liq) v Ultra Tune Australia Pty Ltd (1996) 21 ACSR 457; 14 ACLC 1610; BC9604382 ; Chilcotin Pty Ltd v Cenelage Pty Ltd [1999] NSWCA 11; BC9901346 ; Blunden v Commonwealth [2000] FCA 1581; BC200006777 (leave refused to rely on subsequent High Court decision).

The prohibition against raising new points does not preclude reliance on a deficiency in the pleaded case sought to be established by the opposing party, even if that deficiency was not explicitly relied on at the trial: Ashrafi Persian Trading Co Pty Ltd (t/as Roslyn Gardens Motor Inn) v Ashrafinaia (2002) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-636; [2001] NSWCA 243; BC200104223 ; Hampton Court Ltd v Crooks (1957) 97 CLR 367; 64 ALR (CN) 1201; BC5700440 (“no case” submission raised on appeal after jury trial).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.110] Points that affect the course of evidence

heading.title: Points that affect the course of evidence

p.text: The prohibition against raising new points on appeal is particularly strong where, if the point had been taken at the trial, further evidence might have been led, or it might have been capable of some explanation or qualification: Coulton v Holcombe (1986) 162 CLR 1 at 7–8; 65 ALR 656; BC8601435 (validity of statutory notice); Water Board v Moustakas (1988) 180 CLR 491 at 497; 77 ALR 193; BC8802592 (new particulars of negligence); Suttor v Gundowda Pty Ltd (1950) 81 CLR 418 at 438; 24 ALJR 298 (discretionary defence to specific performance); Symes v Proprietors of Strata Plan No 3 1731 [2003] NSWCA 7; BC200300146 at [38]–[40] (stated case — reliance on new point of law refused); Owston Nominees (No 2) Pty Ltd (2001) 117 FCR 424; [2001] FCA 1833; BC200108132 at [34]–[38], [493]–[497] (illegality); The Tasmania (1890) 15 App Cas 225; Karunaratne v Ferdinandus [1902] AC 405 ; Perkowski v Wellington Corp [1959] AC 53; [1958] 3 All ER 368 ; Ex parte Firth; Re Cowburn (1882) 19 Ch D 419 at 429 .

If it is affirmatively established the point would not have affected the course of evidence, that consideration may provide a basis for allowing the point to be raised: Yorkshire Insurance Co Ltd v Crane (1922) 31 CLR 27 at 39; 28 ALR 361 (point may be raised where it only involves a question of construction); Chalmers Leask Underwriting Agencies v Mayne Nickless Ltd (1983) 155 CLR 279; 49 ALR 149; BC8300101 ; (construction of insurance policy); but will not necessarily do so: Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 at 659–64 .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.115] Points that were deliberately not raised, or that were conceded, at the trial

heading.title: Points that were deliberately not raised, or that were conceded, at the trial

p.text: The fact that the point was deliberately not raised at the trial may be a strong factor against allowing it to be raised on appeal: Hickman v Kent or Romney Marsh Sheep-breeders' Assn (1920) 37 TLR 163 . The same proposition applies where the point was expressly conceded at the trial: Robinson v Campbell (1992) 30 NSWLR 503 . Even in these cases, there is no absolute prohibition. For example, in Pittalis v Grant [1989] QB 605; [1989] 2 All ER 622; [1989] 3 WLR 139 a point of law that had been conceded below was successfully raised on appeal. In Teoh v Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (1994) 121 ALR 436; (1994) 32 ALD 420; 49 FCR 409 an amendment was allowed on appeal to raise a point that had been abandoned at first instance. There are other examples to like effect: Wilson v United Counties Bank [1920] AC 120 (point different from the way the case was conducted below); Ex parte Reddish; Re Walton (1877) 5 Ch D 882 (point inconsistent with arguments put below); Adams v Chas S Watson Pty Ltd (1938) 60 CLR 545 at 548; [1938] ALR 365; BC3800025 (point expressly conceded below). However, these examples all turn on the circumstances of the particular case. They should not be regarded as obscuring the substance, and force, of the general rule against raising new matters on appeal; Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd v Federal Airports Corp (1997) 47 NSWLR 631; BC9705145 (constitutional argument not allowed to be raised on appeal). (The unusual facts in Dovuro Pty Ltd v Wilkins (2001) 107 FCR 104; [2001] FCA 158; BC200100630 show that it may sometimes be important to identify precisely the nature of the point sought to be raised and the nature of the leave required. These considerations may be relevant if the point is taken that the ability to raise the new point is a matter for the individual judges of appeal – rather than mere majority decision: see Dovuro Pty Ltd v Wilkins (2001) 107 FCR 104; [2001] FCA 158; BC200100630 at [14] .)

level.toc-caption: [51.53.120] Points not taken at trial — no absolute bar to reliance on in appeal proceedings

heading.title: Points not taken at trial — no absolute bar to reliance on in appeal proceedings

p.text: Although the prohibition against raising new matters is relatively strictly enforced, there is no absolute bar: Calin v Greater Union Organisation Pty Ltd (1991) 173 CLR 33; 100 ALR 746; BC9102620 ; Burchett v Kane [1980] 2 NSWLR 266 at 277; Donohue v Smith (1947) 48 SR (NSW) 236; 65 WN (NSW) 51 . Appeals (which require leave) against the grant of summary judgment provide a good illustration of a situation where the prohibition may be inappropriate: Dick v University of Queensland [2000] 2 Qd R 476; BC9907416 ; Doherty v Murphy [1996] 2 VR 553; BC9503252 . It has also been suggested that the limitation does not apply with the same force to a respondent who seeks to support the judgment below on a ground other than one that was relied upon at the trial: NRMA Insurance Ltd v B & B Shipping and Marine Salvage Co Pty Ltd (1947) 47 SR (NSW) 273; 64 WN (NSW) 58 ; Simpson v Crowle [1921] 3 KB 243 at 253 ; Osborne & Co v Anderson [1905] VLR 427 ; Waller v Thomas [1921] 1 KB 541 at 547 . More generally, there is a discretion to allow a new point to be relied upon if doing so does not unduly prejudice the other party: Bright v Sampson & Duncan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 346 . The court's task, in determining whether a new point should be able to be raised by an appellant, is to give effect to the demands of justice by balancing, on the one hand, the entitlement of a party to have the case determined according to law and, on the other, the public and private interest in the proper conduct of first instance proceedings: Burston v Melbourne & Metropolitan Tramways Board (1948) 78 CLR 143; [1949] ALR 221; BC4800020 ; McCann v Parsons (1954) 93 CLR 418; [1955] ALR 14; BC5400040 ; Hampton Court Ltd v Crooks (1957) 97 CLR 367; 64 ALR (CN) 1201; BC5700440 ; Sydney Harbour Trust Cmrs v Wailes (1908) 5 CLR 879; 8 SR (NSW) 514 ; Measures v McFadyen (1910) 11 CLR 723; 17 ALR 391; BC1000011 ; Banbury v Bank of Montreal [1918] AC 626 ; Barker v Smith (1907) 7 SR (NSW) 716 ; Field v Sullivan [1923] VLR 70 at 88 .

level.toc-caption: [51.53.125] Points not taken at trial — new points of law raised on appeal

heading.title: Points not taken at trial — new points of law raised on appeal

p.text: The general principles which limit new matters being raised on appeals are intended to serve a broadly stated public interest in the due administration of justice. However, the authorities recognise that the public interest requires a degree of permissive flexibility in the application of the general principles. Consequently, leave may properly be granted where the new matter sought to be raised asserts a material error of law in the disposition of the proceedings below: Holford v Melbourne Tramway & Omnibus Co Ltd [1909] VLR 497; (1907) 13 ALR 667 ; Balenzuela v De Gail (1959) 101 CLR 226 at 233; [1959] ALR 283; BC5900210 ; Burchett v Kane [1980] 2 NSWLR 266 at 277; Connecticut Fire Insurance Co v Cavanagh [1892] AC 473 at 480 (question of construction of a document); Donaghey v P O'Brien & Co [1966] 2 All ER 822; [1966] 1 WLR 1170 ; Della Patrona v DPP (Cth) (No 1) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Priestley and Meagher JJA, 1 September 1995, unreported, BC9501678) (constitutional challenge to legislation). For example, a question of jurisdiction may be raised on appeal if all the relevant facts are in evidence: Norwich Corp v Norwich Electric Tramways Co Ltd [1906] 2 KB 119 ; Westminster Bank Ltd v Edwards [1942] AC 529; [1942] 1 All ER 470 . Similarly, the prohibition applies with diminished force where the alleged error of law relates to a point that is unanswerable: Hampton Court Ltd v Crooks (1957) 97 CLR 367; 64 ALR (CN) 1201; BC5700440 ("no case" submission raised on appeal from jury verdict); White v Ross (1882) 4 ALR 85; Welsh v Anderson (1902) 5 WALR 1 ; Stibbard v Dominion Banking and Investment Corp Ltd (1896) 17 ALT 330; or would otherwise involve the court in dealing with the rights of the parties on a false basis: Brady v Brady [1989] AC 755 at 781; [1988] 2 All ER 617; [1988] 2 WLR 1308 ; Damberg v Damberg (2001) 52 NSWLR 492 ; [2001] NSWCA 87; BC200102714 at [148]–[160] (leave granted to depart from an erroneous assumption about foreign law); Owners of Strata Plan No 50411 v Cameron North Sydney Investments Pty Ltd [2003] NSWCA 5; [2003] NSWCA 5; BC200300132 (leave to challenge non-binding precedent).

level.toc-caption: [51.53.130] Points not taken at trial — costs where appeal succeeds on “new” point not raised at the trial

heading.title: Points not taken at trial — costs where appeal succeeds on “new” point not raised at the trial

p.text: Where the appeal succeeds on a ground not raised at first instance, the successful appellant is ordinarily not entitled to the costs of the appeal: Hussey v Horne-Payne (1878) 8 Ch D 670 ; Ex parte Hauxwell (1883) 23 Ch D 643. However, it may be appropriate to allow part of the costs of the proceedings at first instance: National Australia Bank Ltd v KDS Construction Services Pty Ltd (1987) 163 CLR 668; 76 ALR 27; BC8701823 ; Centronics Systems Pty Ltd v Nintendo Co Ltd (1992) 39 FCR 147; 111 ALR 13 . That possible consideration applies with less force in appeals, or applications for leave to appeal, from the summary determination of proceedings: Jones v Dept of Education [1989] 1 QB 1 (proceedings struck out as not disclosing a cause of action — new points raised): see also SCA s 75A.50 relating to further evidence on such interlocutory appeals.

heading.title: Fraud

p.text: A judgment obtained by fraud may be set aside and a new trial ordered: Jonesco v Beard [1930] AC 298; [1930] All ER Rep 483 ; Hip Foong Hong v H Neotia & Co [1918] AC 888 . Ordinarily, an application to set aside a judgment for fraud ought to be made in separate proceedings: Cabassi v Vila (1940) 64 CLR 130 at 147; [1941] ALR 33; BC4100010 . However, there is jurisdiction to set aside a judgment for fraud on a motion for a new trial, although it will be appropriate to do so only where the fraud is clearly evident on the part of the plaintiff in the conduct of the proceedings below: Cicic v Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority [1964–5] NSWR 178. See further [36.15.20] .

heading.title: Perjury

p.text: A new trial may be granted on the basis of the perjury of a witness: Cicic v Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority [1964–5] NSWR 178; Ladd v Marshall [1954] 3 All ER 745; [1954] 1 WLR 1489 ; McCann v Parsons (1954) 93 CLR 418 at 426; [1955] ALR 14; BC5400040 ; Vasiljev v Public Trustee [1974] 2 NSWLR 497 . However, before a new trial will be ordered on the basis of the perjury, it must be established not only that the evidence of perjury is apparently credible but also that there is a high degree of probability that, at the retrial, there will be a different result: see [51.51.10] above and the cases there cited.

level.toc-caption: [51.53.145] Legal representation — appeal on the ground of inadequacy of at trial

heading.title: Legal representation — appeal on the ground of inadequacy of at trial

p.text: In exceptional cases the manner in which the trial was conducted by a party's legal representative may afford grounds for a new trial: Nudd v R (2006) 225 ALR 161; [2006] HCA 9; BC200601022 at [2], [12]–[19] . Examples of appeals being allowed on this ground are most frequently encountered in criminal proceedings: R v Birks (1990) 19 NSWLR 677 ; Re Knowles [1984] VR 751 ; R v Clinton [1993] 2 All ER 998; [1993] 1 WLR 1181 ; R v McCall (1920) 20 SR (NSW) 467 at 472 . They can also be found in civil proceedings: Chouman v Margules (1993) 17 MVR 144 ; (failure of counsel and judge to refer to material evidence) but the mere exercise of forensic judgment in the course of civil proceedings is most unlikely to afford a ground of appeal: Smits v Roach (2006) 227 CLR 423; 228 ALR 262; [2006] HCA 36; BC200605512 at [46]. In order to sustain an appeal on this ground it is necessary to show more than a mere error of judgment in the manner in which the proceedings were conducted at first instance — otherwise there would be a significant erosion of the principle of finality: Burchett v Kane [1980] 2 NSWLR 266 (note); Seaton v Burnand [1900] AC 135 at 141 . What is required is something in the nature of flagrant or serious incompetence: R v Birks (1990) 19 NSWLR 677 , above.

level.toc-caption: [51.53.150] Reasons for decisions – new trial where inadequate

heading.title: Reasons for decisions – new trial where inadequate

p.text: The extent of the judicial obligation to give reasons is discussed in [36.2.10]–[36.2.25] . Where a trial judge has failed to give adequate reasons the appropriate form of appellate intervention is to order a new trial. This is subject to satisfaction that the failure to give proper reasons involves a “substantial wrong or miscarriage”. That requirement will not be satisfied, and an order for a new trial is not required, where the failure to give reasons involves matters that are not significant to the actual determination of the material issues in the proceedings: Nasr v New South Wales [2007] NSWCA 101; BC200703257 at [22]–[24] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.54] r 51.54 Reinstatement and restitution (cf SCR Part 51, rule 26)

leg:heading.title: Reinstatement and restitution (cf SCR Part 51, rule 26)

p.text: If any step has been taken for the enforcement of a judgment or order that the Court varies or sets aside, the Court may make such orders for reinstatement or restitution as it thinks fit.

heading.title: Note.

p.text: Rule 51.19 provides for how claims for an order for reinstatement or restitution are to be made in appeals and cross-appeals.

heading.title: NOTES
Orders for restitution

p.text: This rule complements the powers of the Court of Appeal under SCA s 75A(10) and permits the court to make any order the nature of the case requires. The power should be seen as requiring the court to make appropriate restitutionary orders: Woolworths Ltd v Strong (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 72; BC201102952 Campbell JA (Handley AJA and Harrison J agreeing). It does not confer a discretion to refrain from making orders for repayment, for example, pending a retrial of the proceedings: TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Antoniadis (No 2) (1999) 48 NSWLR 381 ; or conditionally upon the respondent’s success in the retried proceedings: Wardle v Agricultural and Rural Finance Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 388; BC201210610 at [103] ff. The court's powers in this regard are considered further in [SCA s 75A.55] . Failure to seek orders for repayment at the hearing of the appeal will normally lead to an order that the claimant pay the costs of any further proceedings required to remedy the position: see Production Spray Painting & Panel Beating Pty Ltd v Newnham (No 2) (1992) 27 NSWLR 659 at 663 ; TCN Channel 9, above, at 386; Itek Graphix Pty Ltd v Elliott (No 2) [2002] NSWCA 274; BC200204667 .
Legislation cited in [51.54.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.7.

heading.title: Interest where restitutionary payments required

p.text: Interest is payable as of right, on any moneys required to be repaid as a result of a successful appeal. Amounts subject to this general rule include the judgment debt and costs: Heydon v NRMA Ltd (No 2) (2001) 53 NSWLR 600; [2001] NSWCA 445; BC200108069 at [13]–[14] . Interest is payable at the judgment rate, that is, UCPR r 36.7 , unless sufficient contrary circumstances exist: Heydon, above, at [30]–[33]; cf Cai v Zheng (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 317; BC200909131 at [32] Basten JA (Giles JA and Hoeben J agreeing) (rather than “special circumstance”, the question is whether, in all the circumstances it is appropriate to award interest); Wardle v Agricultural and Rural Finance Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 388; BC201210610 at [108] ff (post judgment interest payable at the rate of interest payable under CPA s 101). The onus lies upon the party seeking the exercise of the court's discretion to depart from the general rule: Heydon, above, at [36]; Roads and Traffıc Authority v Ryan [2002] NSWCA 128; BC200202399 ; Ambulance Service of New South Wales v Worely (No 2) (2006) 67 NSWLR 719; [2006] NSWCA 236; BC200606639 at [34] ; Woolworths Limited v Strong (No 2) [2011] NSWCA 72; BC201102952 especially at [26]–[27] per Campbell JA (Handley AJA and Harrison J agreeing) (the discretion to order restitution following a successful appeal was in the nature of a power that should be exercised, and included the power to award interest).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.55] r 51.55 Short reasons for decision (cf SCR Part 51, rule 59)

leg:heading.title: Short reasons for decision (cf SCR Part 51, rule 59)

p.text: The Court may, when dismissing an appeal, exercise its power under section 45(4) of the Supreme Court Act 1970 to give reasons for its decision in short form.
